content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Without using a meterstick or similar tool, a group of students are to experimentally determine the distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between two horizontal conducting plates by plotting data in a graph. Small nonconducting spheres of varying masses <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> but identical charge <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are able to drop into the space between the horizontal plates through a small hole in the top plate, and come to rest, as shown. The horizontal parallel plates are connected to a variable high-voltage power supply, and the charge of each sphere is determined with an available electrometer. In addition to the equipment described, students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

frqParts.text:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

Without using a meterstick or similar tool, a group of students are to experimentally determine the distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between two horizontal conducting plates by plotting data in a graph. Small nonconducting spheres of varying masses <math alttext="m" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> but identical charge <math alttext="q" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are able to drop into the space between the horizontal plates through a small hole in the top plate, and come to rest, as shown. The horizontal parallel plates are connected to a variable high-voltage power supply, and the charge of each sphere is determined with an available electrometer. In addition to the equipment described, students have access to equipment typically found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the two plates. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a).

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the two plates?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> between the two plates.

(e) After careful analysis of their experimental setup, the group of students find the measurements of potential difference between the two plates measured during the lab are higher values than the actual potential difference across the two plates. Would the error attributed to this finding result in the measured value of <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> being greater than, less than, or equal to the actual value of <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Justify your answer.

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.
